## Problem Kuznetsov Integrals 17-13

## Material from PlusPi
informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by equations in a rectangular coordinate system.

$$
y=1-\ln \cos x, 0 \leq x \leq \frac{\pi}{6}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by equations in a rectangular coordinate system.

$$
y=1-\ln \cos x, 0 \leq x \leq \frac{\pi}{6}
$$ -/
theorem calculus_139060 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = λ x => 1 - log (cos x)) :
    ∫ x in (0)..(π/6), sqrt ((deriv f x)^2 + 1) = log (sqrt 3) := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Let's assume } a_{1}=1, d_{4} \geqslant 2 ; \\
a_{5}=a_{4}+d_{4} \geqslant 6, d_{5} \geqslant \frac{6^{2}}{19-6}>2, d_{5} \geqslant 3 ; \\
a_{6} \geqslant 9, d_{6} \geqslant \frac{9^{2}}{19-9}>8, d_{6} \geqslant 9 ; \\
a_{7} \geqslant 18, d_{7} \geqslant \frac{18^{2}}{19-18}=324 ; \\
a_{8} \geqslant 342>19 .
\end{array}
$$

From this, we can see that $n-1 \leqslant 7, n \leqslant 8$.
On the other hand, the 8 natural numbers $1,2,3,4,6,9,18,342$ meet the conditions of the problem.
Therefore, the maximum value of $n$ is 8.
informal_statement: Four, let $x, y$ be any two numbers in a set of distinct natural numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}$, $\cdots, a_{n}$, and satisfy the condition: when $x>y$, $x-y \geqslant \frac{x}{15}$. Find the maximum number of these natural numbers $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Four, let $x, y$ be any two numbers in a set of distinct natural numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}$, $\cdots, a_{n}$, and satisfy the condition: when $x>y$, $x-y \geqslant \frac{x}{15}$. Find the maximum number of these natural numbers $n$. -/
theorem number_theory_316422 (S : Finset ℕ) (hS : ∀ x ∈ S, ∀ y ∈ S, x ≠ y → x > y → x - y ≥ x / 15) :
    S.card ≤ 8 := by

soln_description:
Explanation: First, let $x_{i}=\sin ^{2} \theta_{i}$, then
$$
0<x_{i} \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \text {. }
$$

Thus, the original inequality is equivalent to
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, x_{4}\right) \\
\geqslant f\left(1-x_{1}, 1-x_{2}, 1-x_{3}, 1-x_{4}\right),
\end{array}
$$

where, $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, x_{4}\right)=\frac{x_{1}^{4}+x_{2}^{4}+x_{3}^{4}+x_{4}^{4}}{x_{1} x_{2} x_{3} x_{4}}$.
Next, recall an IMO pre-selection problem:
Given $\sum_{i=1}^{4} a_{i}^{2}=1$. Prove: $\sum_{1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant 4}^{1}\left(a_{i}+a_{j}\right)^{4} \leqslant 6$. The proof of this problem uses the identity
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant 4}^{1}\left[\left(a_{i}+a_{j}\right)^{4}+\left(a_{i}-a_{j}\right)^{4}\right] \\
=6\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+a_{3}^{2}+a_{4}^{2}\right)^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

By completing the square for $f$, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, x_{4}\right) \\
=\frac{\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{4}+\left(x_{2}-x_{3}\right)^{4}+\left(x_{3}-x_{4}\right)^{4}+\left(x_{4}-x_{1}\right)^{4}}{2 x_{1} x_{2} x_{3} x_{4}}+ \\
\frac{2\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}}{x_{3} x_{4}}+\frac{2\left(x_{3}-x_{4}\right)^{2}}{x_{1} x_{2}}+ \\
\frac{2\left(x_{2}-x_{3}\right)^{2}}{x_{1} x_{4}}+\frac{2\left(x_{4}-x_{1}\right)^{2}}{x_{2} x_{3}}+ \\
{\left[\frac{\left(x_{1}-x_{3}\right)^{2}}{x_{1} x_{3}}+2\right]\left[\frac{\left(x_{2}-x_{4}\right)^{2}}{x_{2} x_{4}}+2\right] .}
\end{array}
$$

Comparing $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, x_{4}\right)$ with $f\left(1-x_{1}, 1-x_{2}\right.$, $\left.1-x_{3}, 1-x_{4}\right)$, the numerators of each term are the same, and in the denominators, since $\frac{1}{x_{i}} \geqslant \frac{1}{1-x_{i}}$, inequality (1) holds.
informal_statement: Example 2 Let $0<\theta_{i} \leqslant \frac{\pi}{4}, i=1,2,3,4$. Prove: $\tan \theta_{1} \cdot \tan \theta_{2} \cdot \tan \theta_{3} \cdot \tan \theta_{4} \leqslant \sqrt{\frac{\sum \sin ^{8} \theta_{i}}{\sum \cos ^{8} \theta_{i}}}$ (2001, China National Training Team Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
